ai_summary: Scanned KCSE result slip with visible KNEC seals, watermark-like background and no obvious image copy-paste artifacts. Forensic metrics (very low ELA and zero copy-move) do not indicate pasted regions. Several black rectangular redactions over name/index fields are present (likely applied after scanning) and OCR failed to extract course codes/GPA values, producing some uncertainty. Overall there is no strong evidence of tampering visible in this single-page scan, but the redactions and OCR gaps merit manual review if original unredacted verification is required.

fraud_signals.signal: Visible official seals and textured background consistent with KNEC security features
Very low ELA score and zero copy-move score (no detected duplicated/pasted regions)
Large black rectangular redactions over name/index area
OCR failed to extract course codes, GPA values and key terms (heuristic counts = 0)
Overall layout and header text consistent with genuine KCSE result slip formatting
Printed date/text contains unusual OCR artifacts (e.g. '2490122'), likely OCR noise

ai_summary: Scanned page appears to be a Kenya National Examinations Council (KNEC) result slip with visible security features (watermark, patterned background, gold seal). Automated heuristics show very low evidence of image splicing or copy-move manipulation. Several black rectangular redactions cover name/ID areas. OCR/heuristics did not extract course codes, GPAs, or typical transcript keywords from the supplied image (likely due to rotation, resolution, or redaction). Overall there is no clear forensic evidence of alteration in the image data, but redactions and missing parsed text warrant routine manual review of the original document if verification is required.

fraud_signals.signal: Visible security features (watermark, patterned background, gold seal) consistent with official KNEC result slips
Low ELA score (0.002) and zero copy-move score indicating no detectable pasted or duplicated regions
Black rectangular redactions covering name/ID areas
OCR/heuristic extraction returned no transcript keywords, course codes, or GPA values
Image is rotated and appears scanned/cropped which reduces automated verification reliability

ai_summary: No clear evidence of document tampering was detected on this scanned transcript page. Image-forensics indicators (copy-move = 0.0, ELA heterogeneity very low) show no duplicated or obviously pasted regions. Academic data are internally consistent: per-course credit × grade-point calculations match the reported semester grade-point totals and derived averages. Visible elements that merit note but do not by themselves indicate fraud include redaction black bars over name/admission fields, an externally applied 'RECEIVED / WSU VANCOUVER' stamp, and OCR transcription errors (e.g., OCR read 'JULY 2082' though the image shows 'JULY 2012'). Overall, the page shows low suspicion for alteration based on the available automated checks and visual review.

ai_summary: Document is a single scanned transcript page from Fourah Bay College (University of Sierra Leone). There is no clear visual evidence of image copy-paste manipulation, but several administrative and content inconsistencies raise concern: the page has no visible student name or ID, several key fields (Cumulative GPA, dates of completion/conferment) are blank, the contact email is a generic Yahoo address rather than an institutional account, and multiple external stamps/marks (e.g., 'RECEIVED', 'WSU VANCOUVER', a date-stamp) appear that could indicate handling by third parties or later stamping. OCR heuristics show few distinct course codes extracted (likely OCR noise) and low ELA / copy-move indicators (no duplicated regions detected). Overall these factors warrant manual review of authenticity and completeness rather than automated classification as definitively forged.

fraud_signals.signal: Missing student identifiers and core conferral fields (no visible student name, student ID, date of completion/conferment, qualification obtained)
Contact email is a generic Yahoo address (fbc_usl1827@yahoo.com) instead of an institutional domain
Multiple external stamps/annotations present (e.g., 'RECEIVED', 'WSU VANCOUVER', a date-stamp) which are not part of the issuing institution's standard header
Low count of distinct course codes in OCR output relative to the visible table (heuristic course_code_count=4 vs many table rows) — likely OCR extraction failure, could hide inconsistencies
No copy-move duplication detected (copy_move_score=0.0) and ELA score very low indicating homogeneous compression rather than heterogeneous editing
Blank Cumulative GPA and other summary fields on the page (CGPA area left empty) which may indicate an incomplete page or cropped/missing supplementary pages
Unusual wording/typos in printed text (e.g., 'PLEASE DISREGARD TRANSCRIPT LF SEAL IS FOUND BROKEN') — could be OCR errors but also atypical phrasing for an official form

Automated image-forensics (ELA and copy-move) do not show strong evidence of pasted-in regions or duplicated blocks.

Low ELA heterogeneity score (no strong local compression/contrast anomalies detected)

ai_summary: Scanned page contains only a short header-like line: an identifier 'K.C.S.E' and number '4222484' plus a QR code. There are no course listings, grades, GPA values, term labels, registrar or 'official/unofficial/transcript' markers, and OCR/heuristic metrics indicate a very sparse capture (low character and line counts). No clear copy-paste artifacts were detected by the provided image-forensics scores. The page is consistent with an incomplete/cropped scan or an isolated header image rather than a full transcript; this absence of expected academic detail warrants manual review and, if this is intended to be a complete transcript page, further verification with the issuing institution.

ai_summary: Scanned page is almost entirely blank white with a small QR code at the top-left. OCR and provided heuristics found no transcript keywords, no registrar/official wording, no course codes, and no GPA/term data. Image-level tamper detectors (ELA, copy-move) report no anomalies. The absence of any typical transcript content on the page is highly suspicious for an official transcript page (could be a blank/back page, an incomplete scan, or an intentionally substituted page). Recommend manual review and request of a complete page set or higher-quality scan.

ai_summary: The image appears to be a degree certificate/diploma issued by The University of Sierra Leone / Fourah Bay College (degree: Bachelor of Social Science with Honours in Social Work, class: Second Class Second Division, dated December 2016) rather than a multi-line academic transcript listing courses, terms, and GPA. The scan shows multiple ink stamps (including a consular-style blue round stamp with a handwritten date 09/05/2023), several handwritten signatures, an embossed seal impression at the bottom center, and at least two black rectangular redaction boxes obscuring personal data. Automated image heuristics show no evidence of copy-move duplication and a very low ELA anomaly score. Overall there are no clear signs of pixel-level pasted text or duplicated regions; the main concern is the mismatch between expected transcript content (course codes, term entries, GPAs) and the provided certificate page. Manual review recommended to confirm whether a diploma was submitted in place of a transcript and to verify the authenticity of the applied stamps/seals through issuing authorities.

fraud_signals.signal: Document content matches a degree/certificate (diploma) layout rather than a multi-line academic transcript with course codes, terms, and GPA.
No course listings, term words, or GPA values present on the page (course_code_count=0; gpa_values empty).
Multiple applied stamps (blue round consular-style stamp dated 09/05/2023) and overlapping handwritten dates/signatures present.
Automated image forensics show near-zero copy-move score and very low ELA anomalies (copy_move_score=0.0; ELA_score=0.0028) indicating no obvious pasted or duplicated regions.
Solid black rectangular redactions over name/identifier areas (visible blocks) which obscure identity fields.
Presence of printed border, institutional crest, and an embossed seal impression consistent with a formally produced diploma/certificate.

ai_summary: Document is a scanned transcript for Fourah Bay College (University of Sierra Leone). Visual inspection finds multiple strong layout anomalies that increase the probability of tampering: several identical course codes are used for different course descriptions across the table (e.g., SOW 111 appears with different course titles; SOW120 and SOW110 appear more than once with different descriptions). A large circular stamp and handwritten certification overlap cells in the grade table (partially obscuring entries). Automated image heuristics show no clear copy-paste duplication, but the duplicated course-code mappings and overlapping stamp are suspicious and warrant manual review of the source file and original institutional records. Overall risk level: MEDIUM.

fraud_signals.signal: Duplicate course codes mapped to different course descriptions (e.g., SOW 111 listed as both 'INTRODUCTION TO SOCIAL WORK' and 'INTRODUCTION TO SOCIOLOGY'; SOW120 and SOW110 appear more than once with different descriptions).
Large circular stamp and handwritten 'Certified' annotation overlap the grade table and some grade cells, which could obscure or mask edits to grades/entries.

Automated copy-move / duplicated-region analysis returned no detectable duplicated regions (copy_move_score = 0.0) and low ELA heterogeneity (ELA_score ~0.0038), suggesting no obvious digital paste/detection of cloning artifacts.

Numeric summaries and grade-point totals shown on the page are noisy and appear inconsistent in the OCR text (e.g., sum/average placements and numeric labels are unclear); cannot confirm arithmetic consistency from the scan alone.
Header contains informal-looking contact (a Yahoo address) and some typographic noise in the printed header; while not definitive of fraud, this is atypical for many modern official transcripts.

Document includes official-seal wording 'PLEASE DISREGARD TRANSCRIPT IF SEAL IS FOUND BROKEN' and multiple stamps/signatures; presence of stamps is normal for attestation but their placement over data cells increases review necessity.

Image-level forensic indicators (ELA and copy-move) do not show obvious pasted regions or duplicated content. Several course-code repetitions and noisy rows are present in the OCR output but could be OCR/layout errors rather than intentional alteration.
